chapter.title: Setting up vmimagemanager.cfg
chapter.para: vmimagemanager.cfg follows the file format of a standard p[ython cfg file commonly known as a 'ini' file.
The vmimagemanager.cfg is broken down into sections, one global section and a section for each slot.

section.title: Configuration vmimagemanager.cfg Section "VmImageManager"
section.para: The "VmImageManager" section of the vmimagemanager.cfg is the global section of vmimagemanager.cfg.
&vmim; manages your snapshots of an OS to devices and a large image store location. This path is set.on my server this space is mounted under /server/vmstore.

section.title: Depricated: Xen Pre 0.1.0 tempalating system
section.para: This is documented here as I feel that this aproach has some merrit, and it is intended that static template files be murged with vmimagemanger again so the following section is preserved. Please send in a bug request if the idea of template files apeals.
The Generated configurations for Xen and for the templates to generate them (Q: should posibly be in a /var/lib/ directory ?) are by default in the /etc/vmimagemanager

section.title: Configuration vmimagemanager.cfg Section for a slot
section.para: All sections of vmimagemanager.cfg except the "VmImageManager" section are per Virtual maschine configuration files. LibVirt also has a concept of defined hosts, if a defined host is deleted, &vmim; will redefine it based on the settings in these slots on execution.

Settings will only be applied to current virtual maschines if the maschine is deleted then &vmim; will recreate the virtual maschine based upon the configuration sections, including registering the diesks with the virtualisation frame work.
As a minimum, to define a slot, hostname, network connections and stroage must be defined.
Two slots from a vmimagemanager.cfg as an example
section.programlisting:
[virt_yokel_org] vm_slot_enabled=on HostName=DebianStable root=/dev/hda5 swap=/dev/hda10 mount=/mnt/virt.yokel.org host=virt.yokel.org mac=02:11:62:22:21:13
[vm001.yokel.org] vm_slot_enabled=on HostName=vm001.yokel.org root=/dev/hda11 swap=/dev/hda12 mount=/mnt/vm001.yokel.org host=virt.yokel.org mac=02:01:63:22:51:13
section.para: The section names, are not important and must only be unique, in the above example the slots are called virt_yokel_org and vm001.yokel.org
The HostName is set to the name that matches the &vm; through libvirt.
The mac is set to the mac address to use with the &vm; I usually use dhcp to manage networking with &vm;'s.

section.title: Setting up a slots storage.
section.para: Due to the need to support &kvm; and &xen; paravirtualised, &vmim; supports two ways of setting up the storage for a &vm;.

section.title: Setting up a slots storage as disks.
section.para: This mechanism is generally used for all forms of virtualisation using raw disk images, and is the recomended mechanism for &kvm; and fully virtualised &xen;.

section.title: Setting up a slots storage as partitions.
section.para: Using this apraoch partitions are parsed directly to the &vm; rather than complete disks. As far as we know this is the only supported on &xen; paravirtaulised.

section.title: Getting a MAC Address for your &vm;
section.para: If you want how to get the mac address of a configured host. The admisn at DESY have come up with a nice convention.

itemizedlist.listitem: Fill up every part with zero. 131.169.226.057
Replace the 2 first digit with 02 (this is an undefined MAC adress range) 021.169.226.057
Remove the dots, and the result is our unique virtual machine mac address 021169226057

section.para: With this aproach you can assign a sensible MAC address to all your &vm;'s.
